Spotlight is a movie that is about information, yes it's also about the infamous scandal within the Catholic Church as well as the brave news team (and paper) that decided to against one of the oldest, most powerful organizations in history, but it's also about information. To clarify, Spotlight feels like a film that feels based around facts and knowledge and discovering them, Aaron Sorkin did this sort of thing with The Social Network, discovering new technology or a new world that most people didn't really understand and bringing us into it. Spotlight is similar, but it takes it in a different direction. Instead it takes us into a world that we have all come to know too well, when the evils that the church was covering up were revealed it became everything from the spark of protests to the butt of jokes. Spotlight is taking us back to when it was discovered but also shows us the magnitude of this scandal, the hidden horrors behind every good cause that can be gigantic. Yet it's not just about discovering information and simply about condemnation, but it's also a story about the importance of discovering information. The film mainly follows the Spotlight team, sparing little expense for their personal lives, how could it when there's so much information that needs to be calculated and compiled into the script which plays out everything we need to know and that we find interesting. It follows along the lines of introducing us to fact after fact that the Spotlight team discovers through many different fascinating methods. The screenplay which is one of the best of this year takes a story of such density and such complexity and brings it to life before our eyes, and it does so in such capable hands. The director clearly had this in mind, McCarthy goes for a straightforward style with his approach within the film, it's pace, stillness, and necessity is what guides his film. It's the kind of story that doesn't exactly requires a straightforward kind of presentation, it tries to tell it as it is through it's visuals rather than tell it's story through them. In most films this would be understand as sloppy, poorly done filmmaking but not so here. Looking at the staging, the choice of camera position, and the urge to (as Sasha puts it in the film) to tell the story right. Guided by a stellar cast with few weak points and Keaton who is making his comeback last more than just an under-appreciated performance but now has thrust himself into a role that's the definition of great acting, he doesn't act but allows himself to be absorbed into the film, he's a human being who is almost indistinguishable from Keaton himself. He heads the acting ensemble despite his lack of leading role and is supported by his fellow cast mates. Putting all of this together we get Spotlight, a deftly written, impeccably crafted showcase of modern filmmaking that is easily one of the year's best.

Spotlight does justice to an incredible true story through its faith towards and deep understanding of the real events. It's eye opening to witness the discovery of this massive scandal with the catholic church, showing just how important investigative journalism is. The film has quite the ensemble cast with some really good performances. Michael Keaton and Mark Ruffalo really capture the essence of their characters (I'd know because we saw them at an interview after the screening) and closely embody many details including speech and physical mannerisms. Liev Schreiber and Stanley Tucci were also standouts with their characters. Rachel McAdams was good, too, but she's not doing anything we haven't seen her do before. There isn't quite a main character in the film, and we don't go very deep into any particular character. This is mostly forgivable because what the characters are tackling is much bigger than they are. Even though we don't feel the story much through any particular character, we feel it effectively as a whole. That isn't to say that the performances lack depth, however. Several of the actors do a great job of conveying a passion for justice in their work, particularly Keaton and Ruffalo, who are the clear and equal standouts in the film. Thomas MacCarthy is great at making the audience feel like they're really experiencing this investigation as it unfolds. It's hard to find wasted screen time as the story is constantly moving. The screenplay, which is apparently incredibly accurate, is concise and full of intelligent and witty dialogue that propels each minute of this thriller paced drama. Watching the film, we are put right in the center of several major discoveries like just how big of a problem child molestation is in the Catholic Church and how the church has gotten an entire country to sweep the scandal under the rug. It shows how such a large situation can go unnoticed by the word, despite its massive size, and this is a shocking discovery that we make as the Spotlight crew does. The film is a perfect homage to investigative journalism, honoring the heroes of the Spotlight team and the victims who come forward to help justice surface. Spotlight shows that the time to act is the time when you're told to keep your mouth shut. It would be hard to imagine a film depicting the many layers of how this story was uncovered and celebrating those who sought out the truth better than Spotlight does. The broad approach certainly pays off in a satisfying way, but I can't help but feel that the film may have been even more moving if it took a more intimate approach. It's a slight loss that we don't really connect with any characters, especially when it's clear that the film could have done so without diminishing the overall impact. Still, Spotlight gets so much right that it's hard to complain. This is a really incredible story and it's great to feel that MacCarthy and his crew know it.

I had the opportunity to catch a sneak screening of this film a week prior to its release and want to draw some attention to it and its undeniable quality as it will likely, ironically enough, fail to ever find the spotlight butting head-to-head with Spectre being released the same weekend. There will always (arguably) be another James Bond movie or over-the-top action film similar to it, but Spotlight is a rare film this year that would be a shame to miss and deserves every bit of attention it will likely receive come award season.Spotlight is a film imbued with an intrinsic sense of subtlety and deference. It doesn't dwell on Hollywood-isms or trick the audience with convenient plot twists and escapist subplots and drama. Spotlight is, at its core, bare-knuckled, by-the-books, calculated, and precisely executed. It only reaches as far as the scope of the story that inspired the film demands. As a minor consequence, it can come off as dry and somber at times, but this film has so many other things going for it that it never really seems to drag.If Spotlight had been told in any other way with any other cast, it likely would have either parted from a truthful, realistic depiction of the actual events or came across as the largest bore of 2015. To be fair, however, the story itself is compelling in its own right and is likely to relate to any audience member bold enough to sit through a film of this type. It was actually a very dense film with little intrigue beyond the cast and premise, but it was told in such a convincing way that to give it anything other than my full attention would have felt disrespectful. It really felt like it was just a few great acting performances away from actually turning into a documentary, and likely would have been just as effective as such.So let's get into what really matters in a film of this style and caliber: the performances. As one would expect given the rave reviews of the film already and the names attached to this title, the performances are spectacular all around. Michael Keaton has toned down from his over-dramatic, schizophrenic Birdman role to a far more calm, self-serious, motivated character in Spotlight. Keaton's character, however, is never really given a chance to shine and pales in comparison to the character played by Mark Ruffalo who, in my opinion, stole the show. He plays his typical investigation-related role that he's played at least ten times now, although his performance reminded me most clearly of not his, but Jake Gyllenhaal's character in Zodiac. Instead of calm and suave as per usual, he now plays the overly passionate, sociopathic type that doesn't seem to get a wink of rest from the start to the end of the film in so desperately trying to uncover the mystery beneath it all. Rachel McAdams is great, too. And it only feels right for her to be in this, immediately following her role in the second season of True Detective which was likewise plagued by the complication of dealing with too many indistinguishable names and characters.I should sidetrack briefly and admit to one flaw I felt fell upon the movie a bit for me and that was the complication of dealing with so many different leads, victims, alleged criminals and so on and so forth. It would be criminal not to include all of these names as they all served as individual cogs used to propel the narrative along. I just almost wish they weren't introduced at such a rapid pace, or at least that each name was given equal weight. I nodded my head at the times where characters would recall details of the person being described to help me remember him or her, but other times so many names of people never physically shown on camera would be thrown in the mix simply for the purpose of reference that I began to find myself a little lost. Perhaps that's just me. I just felt at times characters didn't elaborate upon perceptibly crucial details as well as some procedural films similar to it.Nevertheless, each character portrayed felt human, emotionally charged and vibrant, relatable, and important. Spotlight did such a good job portraying each character and just enough detail of their back stories evenly that it's almost hard to say who the main character of the film really even was. An argument could be made somewhere between Ruffalo, Keaton, and McAdams, but even between the three of them each character is covered to a pretty even degree. I loved that about this movie because it helped everything seem level. No one character was heralded or glamorized above another and each member of the Boston Globe editorial team portrayed contributed to the development of the narrative in their own unique ways, as it would have been in reality.This film is tonally consistent, fair and respectful of its subject matter, emotionally driven, well-acted, thought-provoking, deftly-paced, and even appears to have an exceptional sense of direction both in terms of narrative and style. Director Tom McCarthy handled the true story perfectly in a way that never came off as expository or shameful, but rather enlightening and powerful. All around Spotlight is a well-made, tightly-crafted, and tense drama revolving around a topic that threatens to shake society's faith of the religious institution, as it did for me. They don't make many movies quite like this anymore. With the attention span of much of the modern audience there isn't much room for attention to be drawn to this type of film anymore outside of Oscar buzz, and the box office numbers prove it time and again. So do Hollywood some justice and see BOTH Spectre AND Spotlight on November 6th when they're released in the US.

SPOTLIGHT is that rare film that takes a true event and delves into it with razor-sharp focus while employing a straightforward no-nonsense approach; it refuses to resort to ubiquitous movie-like scenarios - there is no fluff, no dazzle, no unnecessary drama, no corny subplots, and none of those moments we have come to associate with "cheesy" and "Hollywood." Instead, what Tom McCarthy has brought to the table is a tightly written script about work and process - the ensemble is excellent as they merge into their real-life counterparts and bring to life the strategies and dedication and sacrifice their characters must go through in order to reach their desired outcome (while fighting against the Catholic Church, no less). This is easily one of the least flashy but most thrilling and rejuvenating films of the year.

Exemplifying the pillars of journalistic integrity, Spotlight provides one of the most intense situations in recent domestic American history, the Catholic church, and multiple lawyers, being questioned in their defense of sanctioned pedophilia and its victims. From the opening shot, the fluidity between actors is well displayed, the spotlight team (comprised of Keaton, Ruffalo, McAdams, and James), working in tandem with one another, the script and performance of each actor giving an eerily natural flow from one scene to the next. Schreiber and Slattery don't have as much screen time as the aforementioned, but their unique characters give enough oomph to the plot line. With a muted piano & bass-heavy score, only the sounds of the streets of Boston as well as the office of The Boston Globe to accompany the sound profile, the film in itself is an edge-of-the-seat dramatic piece. The reason I believe it's one of the best films I've seen in a very long time is resonant in the fact that it characterizes the sheer tenacity of integrous/virtuous journalists, rooting through the murky legislation and human will that surrounds this scandal. A must watch.
